biogHist.abstract: Carrolup, near Katanning, was a government-run 'native settlement' which had been closed in 1922 and was and re-opened by the Department of Native Affairs in 1939. By 1944, there were 129 boys, girls and older children in government 'care' at Carrolup. In 1951, the government withdrew most of the children from Carrolup and it was re-opened as a Marribank Farm School.
biogHist.p: Carrolup, near Katanning, was a government-run 'native settlement' which had been closed in 1922 and was and re-opened by the Department of Native Affairs in 1939. By 1944, there were 129 boys, girls and older children in government 'care' at Carrolup. Children at Carrolup were under the guardianship of the Commissioner for Native Affairs.

The Sunday Times reported in 1947 that Native Affairs Minister Ross McDonald said 'much interest was evidenced in the recent exhibition of drawings of children of Carrolup school for natives exhibited in Perth. All the pictures were purchased and realised &pound74, which will be expended in the interests of the children.'
In 1949, the school at Carrolup closed and school-age children were transferred to other missions according to their religious denominations.

In September 1949, former Carrolup schoolboys Barry Loo and Mervyn Smith became the first Aboriginal people to be employed in the Western Australian public service. They were engaged as clerical assistants at the Department of Native Affairs in Perth.

On 17 June 1951, Carrolup Native Settlement was closed and the Department of Native Affairs reported that the adults were 'dispersed' but that teenage boys were kept there to establish Marribank Farm Training School.

chronItem.event: Location - Carrolup [II] was located on 2,000 hectares of land that lay on the banks of the Carrolup and Carlocatup Rivers between Katanning and Kojonup

descriptiveNote.p: Carrolup closed for 17 years but was eventually re-opened by the government in 1939 on the same site, using the same buildings.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Department of Native Affairs, State of Western Australia (1936 - 1954)
Show us a light [videorecording]: the art of Carrolup (1980s)

descriptiveNote.p: The 'Stolen Generations' policy of removing children from their families and placing them in institutions has had a long term impact in Western Australia. This been seen as an ongoing factor in the disproportionately high number of Aboriginal children being placed in out of home care in this State, long after the official policies ended.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: State Archives Collection of Western Australia (1829 - )
Department of Aboriginal Affairs [predecessors], Records, Department of Aboriginal Affairs (1886 - 2004)
Department for Child Protection and Family Support [and its predecessors] Records (1894 - )
Taskforce to Identify the scope and extent of the 'stolen wages' issue, and to suggest policy options and administration issues [Stolen Wages Taskforce] (2007 - 2008)

descriptiveNote.p: The Taskforce to Identify the scope and extent of the 'stolen wages' issue included practices at Carrolup [II] in its investigations.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Stolen Wages Reparation Scheme WA, State of Western Australia (2012)

descriptiveNote.p: Aboriginal people born before 1958 who earned unpaid wages at Carrolup [II] were eligible to apply for the Stolen Wages Reparation Scheme WA.
Carrolup Native Settlement sometimes transferred children to Roelands Native Mission Farm.
Moore River Native Settlement sometimes transferred children to Carrolup Native Settlement
When Carrolup was discontinued as a 'native settlement', some children were sent to Wandering Mission.

archref.abstract: 'Children at Carrolup Native Settlement, early 1940s [picture]' is an image from the State Library of Western Australia's collection of online images that were made available by the Historical Records Rescue Consortium Project supported by Lotterywest.

'Rabbits enemies [picture]' is an image from the State Library of Western Australia's collection of online images. It is a copy of a drawing in the school book of Revel Cooper, who was a child at Carrolup.
